claim.statement: Plumbers with names that begin with an A or a number receive more than five times as many complaints with the Better Business Bureau.
claim.hypothesis: Firms that use names beginning with an A or a number will receive more complaints than firms not using names beginning with an A or a number.

datasets.name: Plumbing firms dataset from Illinois

summary_statistics.info: This dataset contains information on plumbing firms including company name, phone number, address, and characteristics such as number of employees and advertisement spending.

access.restrictions: Data derives from ReferenceUSA and is proprietary.

datasets.notes: Data sourced from ReferenceUSA, includes self-reported and verified corporate data.

files.Data Analysis Code for McDevitt JPE.Rmd: This R markdown file contains data reading and analysis scripts to perform Ordinary Least Squares (OLS) regression on complaints data to evaluate the study's main hypothesis.
files.Plumbings_RCodes.R: This R script automates data scraping from Better Business Bureau for plumbing firms in Illinois, collects complaints data, and merges it with existing ReferenceUSA datasets.

codebase.notes: The codebase requires R with packages such as readr, estimatr, tidyverse, stringr, rvest, and httr for data manipulation, scraping, and analysis.

method.description: This observational study analyzes how the naming conventions of plumbing firms affect the volume of complaints filed against them, using complaints data from the Better Business Bureau.
steps: Compile data on plumbing firms from ReferenceUSA.
Scrape complaints data from the Better Business Bureau.
Merge datasets and extract relevant columns.
Conduct statistical analysis using OLS regression to test the hypothesis.

results.summary: The study found that firms with names beginning with 'A' or a number received significantly more complaints than other firms, suggesting these naming practices attract less informed, low-willingness-to-search customers.

metadata.original_paper_title: “A” Business by Any Other Name: Firm Name Choice as a Signal of Firm Quality

analysis.instructions: Run the R markdown file 'Data Analysis Code for McDevitt JPE.Rmd' to replicate the main regression analysis. Verify that all package dependencies are installed.
analysis.comparison_metrics: Compare incident rate ratio and complaint frequency as primary metrics across original and potential replication datasets.
